ROBERT FIELD: So today, it's
my favorite topic, dynamics.

And I think the main point
I'm going to be making

is that, mostly, we use
dynamics to explore what's

in an effective Hamiltonian. We don't observe
dynamics directly.

And that's the nature of the
game for frequency domain spectroscopy. You measure a spectrum,
and you fit it.

And once you have done that, you
have an effective Hamiltonian. And once you have an
effective Hamiltonian,

you often don't
know what's in it. It's a fit model. It can tell you a lot about what
the molecule is actually doing.

It takes the ingredients
you put into it and transforms
them into something

more than you knew, initially. What is an effective
Hamiltonian? It's a zero order model.

And it's some couplings. Now, there are many
possible zero order models.

And the nice thing about
an effective Hamiltonian is that it provides a fit to
observations to the spectrum.

It accounts for
everything you observe. And that's all you ask of it.

But then, you've got this thing. And it might be able
to tell you about ways

to design clever
experiments for controlling

the dynamics of the system, or
visualizing what's going on, observing the emergence of
qualitatively new classes

of motion in the molecule. And it's really, to
me, an amazing thing

that a stupid model can
convey deep insights that

were not explicitly sought
when you constructed the model.

And so what I'm going
to do is, really,

an unconventional lecture,
because, most of the time,

when people talk about
dynamics, the dynamics

are the thing that one measures. Or it's the endpoint,
rather than a byproduct

of what we do in the spectrum. And so, anyway, we'll see
whether I can give you

some surprising insights. OK, so what I'm
going to do is just, on the first page
of the notes is

an outline of all of the
things that I plan to touch on.

And let's talk through this. The first dynamical
example is quantum beats,

because the quantum beat is the
first and simplest case where you have a two-level system.

And it does something which is
different from an eigenstate. And there's a lot of
insights from that.

And the next key
thing is to talk about the concept of a bright
state and a dark state.

There is nothing absolute
about brightness and darkness. It depends on the definition
of the experiment.

Some of the most
important developments in small and medium
sized molecule

spectroscopy come from ways
in which people have cleverly

created new classes
of bright states, because each class
of bright state

enables a very specific
pluck of this system.

And then, you can
observe how the pluck-- how the system
responds to that pluck.

And that can provide insights
into important coupling mechanisms but, also, can
reveal energy flow pathways,

the occurrence of
unexpected things. And the experiment that--

well, there are several
kinds of plucks.

One kind of pluck involves
large amplitude, local mode

excitations, which is
what people initially did in the early
days of dynamics,

when people were trying to
do bond specific chemistry. And there were all
of these Rh stretches

that appeared in
the visible region. And there was a belief
that, if you could just

use those to put a lot of energy
into a single vibrational mode,

and that would activate
the molecule for chemistry at that location.

And that went for a long way. But stretching motions,
especially on the periphery

of a molecule, are
not very strongly coupled into the
many body dynamics

that a molecule can undergo. And so I invented
stimulated emission pumping,

which enabled a bright
state that involved

large amplitude skeletal modes. And instead of just being able
to excite high overtones of Rh

stretches, you could excite
several different classes of modes. And you could even know
what the nature of that

was initially, because it's
governed by the [INAUDIBLE] principle. Brooks Pate had a
kind of pluck that

had to do with knowing
the rotational constant of different isomers. And so, by looking at
the rotational spectrum

in the region of the
rotational constants

for different isomers, he's
visualizing different--

he separates one
isomer from another. And that's, really, to me, a
mind blowing sort of pluck.

OK, so the concept of
bright and dark states
is going to be really important. Then, there's another issue. And that is nonradiative decay.

There was-- around
the time that I

was starting my
scientific career, there was an enormous
dispute about,

what do polyatomic molecules
that are electronically excited

do? They-- you know you've excited
a certain number of them with--

by-- when you absorb photons. And when you do that, you expect
a certain number of photons

out. And you also expect
a certain decay rate. And molecules seem to decay
faster than you expected.

And the quantum yields
were very small. And there was a huge
controversy about,

what is the reason for this? And one, the best thing that
people could come up with

was that polyatomic molecules
electronically excited

are exceptionally
sensitive to quenching. And all of these issues,
these photochemical issues

could be resolved, simply,
by going to lower-- low enough pressure
that, eventually, you

would get out of the
quenching regime. And all of these anomalies
would be resolved.

And that turns out to be wrong. But the people who believed
in quenching, collisional

quenching were
exceedingly resistant, because, if there's this
idea that a molecule is

an exceptionally
sensitive, well, then you can never prove you're
wrong, because you could just

say, well, it's more sensitive. And you haven't gone
to low enough pressure. As you go to lower and lower
pressure, signal goes away.

And so, one needed
an answer to this, an explanation that
says, OK, we can

account for these phenomena. And that's Bixen Jortner theory. And we'll talk about
that a little bit.

Maybe I should just launch

One, they're never negative. Two, they're real.

They're never greater than 1. And so, this thing ought to

OK, well, I'm going

And so, this leads to the idea

or so-- quantum beats.

If we have a bright
state and a dark state,

well, then, this looks like
the system is periodically--

it starts out in
the bright state, because we know that's
what we plucked. It leaves the bright
state, and it comes back.

And so, we have what's called
population quantum beats.

And if it's a
bright state, you've excited this quantum
beating system. It's going to fluoresce.

And the fluorescence
intensity is going to be decreasing exponentially.

But it's going to
have superimposed on the exponential decay. It's going to have--

whoops, it's going to
have 100% quantum beats.

And no matter how
you look at this, if you excite a
bright state, you can look at the fluorescence
from any direction.

And by choosing some direction
and some polarization,
nothing changes. You have 100% amplitude beats.

And-- but then,
there's another thing. There's polarization
quantum beats.

Suppose you have,
say, m equals 0. And you have-- you use
perpendicular polarization.

And you excite to m equals
minus 1, m equals plus 1.

So suppose you had
x or y polarization. Well, then, a
pulse could produce
two levels of different m.

And so, then
depending on how you look at the fluorescence,
in what direction, with what

polarization, you will see beats
always at the same frequency.

But amplitude the
amplitude of the modulation will depend on what polarization
state you're looking at.

And so, what happens is, for
polarization quantum beats,

the angular distribution of the
fluorescence is not isotropic.

The total intensity
of the fluorescence is a function of time,
is simple exponential.

But because you've excited
the sample and isotopically, it's a beacon that's rotating.

And you're seeing how
this thing is moving. So there's this simple idea that
came from some of the earliest

time dependent experiments
where, one observed two classes of quantum beats,
one where the fluorescence was

turning on and off,
and the other where the fluorescence
was moving around in a complicated
and angular way.

And a lot was
learned about that.
OK, so this is--

so I've been talking about
quantum beating system where we have two states.

One state does not radiate. Now, it does not radiate
at all, as opposed to,

it does not radiate
into your detector. You could have a detector
which is sensitive to radiation

from one of the eigenstates
and not from the other, as opposed to a
system where there

is no fluorescence from one
of the to zero order states,

because, let's say, it's
a singlet and a triplet. And the triplet has
a long lifetime. And the singlet has
a short lifetime.

And so, to a good
approximation, one radiates, the other one doesn't. And so, if you knew
the radiative decay

rates for the bright state and
the dark states, what would

you see in the fluorescence? What would be the
modulation depth?

What would be the
decay of the nonbeating

part of the fluorescence? And what would be the
decay rate of the beat?

So you can express everything in
terms of the two level problem

and the properties of these
two zero order states.

And I don't-- I'm not going to require
you to hand this in. But I do recommend that
you explore this problem,

because there's
going to be something

about the decay of the
nonbeating part which is built from these-- the lifetimes of
these two states.

And there's going
to be something about the decay of
the quantum beating

part of the system, the
fluorescence, which is built from these two lifetimes. And you have an
overdetermined system

that if you know
something about the-- it's really two levels,
one bright, and one dark.

You should be able to
develop a relationship

between the decay of the beat
and the decay of the nonbeat.

OK so, you could
also do a problem

where you have
two bright states. One-- they both radiate
at different rates.

But one radiates in a wavelength
region that your detector sees.

And one radiates in a
wavelength region the detector doesn't see. And again, how
would that translate

into the observable decays
of the nonbeat and beat?

OK, so now, nonradiative decay,
and as I said, the 1960s were--

was a period where
people were fighting about nonradiative decay.

So thermodynamically,
you can know the energy at which a molecule, a
polyatomic molecule will break,

either by dissociating
or by ionizing. And so, if you excite
from the ground state

to some excited state-- and up here is the lowest
fragmentation channel,

you know you're making something
that isn't going to go away.

And you also know that you
can measure the absorption

coefficient for this transition. And people did that
a lot, up until--

well, people continue to do it. But it was one of the
standard things you could do. And so, you did
it, because you--

and so, up until
the mid '60s, there were an awful lot
of measurements

of absolute absorption
coefficients for polyatomic molecules. And there's a simple theory
that relates the absorption

coefficient, which
is an Einstein B coefficient, to the decay
rate, which is an Einstein A

coefficient. And one can do the theory
well enough so that,

if you know what the absorption
coefficient is and you know that this thing can only
radiate to levels that you

have understood, then you
can calculate what is-- what the radiative
lifetime will be.

And there isn't any
slop about that. And if you know what the
absorption coefficient is

and you know what
the pressure is, you know how many
molecules you've excited.

So you can measure the
fluorescence quantum yield.

And you can do it
the absolute way, where you measure the number
of photons in and the number

of photons out. Or you can measure it a clever
way, which is the predicted--

so you can have the radiative
decay rate, plus total decay

rate. This ratio is the
quantum [INAUDIBLE] also. So we have a radiative
plus nonradiative decay.

This is radiative
plus nonradiative. This is just one of the two. But before people admitted there
could be a nonradiative decay,

the only thing people did was
to measure photons in, photons out and measure lifetimes.

And what they found was
that the lifetimes-- or the decay rate
for fluorescence

from a polyatomic
molecule excited to a nonfragmenting
state was always faster.

Sure, the lifetime
was always shorter than what you calculate. And the quantum yield was
always less than 1, and usually

by enormous factors. And so, the question
was, well, why is this?

And at that time, the eigenstate
picture was the whole story.

And eigenstates-- all
an eigenstate can do-- it's not really an
eigenstate if it fluoresces.

But so, we fixed that up. We say, eigenstates can
fluoresce by some magic.

But then, it was
a simple theory. And why did this happen?

And so, there was
a group of people, of whom, the person who taught
me quantum mechanics, Martin

Gouterman, was the leader,
believed that this was all due to collisional quenching.

And along came
Bixen and Jortner.

There was a lot-- there
were a lot of people.

And there's, actually--
and Klemperer, all of them

got credit for this idea was

were Bixen and Jortner. And what Bixen and Jortner
said is, let's generalize
on quantum beats. Suppose you have a bright state.

And you have a dense manifold of
dark states, not one but many.

And in order-- this was before
we had good computers also. So it was necessary to
write this problem in a form

where you could
solve it exactly, without using a computer.

And so, what they
did is they said, OK, we have a dense manifold
of dark states, equally spaced.

And they all have the same
coupling matrix element with the bright state. This is an exactly
soluble toy problem.

And so, one can,
then, distribute

the bright character. So you get a new manifold of
states where there's one more

state than the dark states. And their bright
character is distributed

in a Lorentzian way. And so, if you were to
excite it with a short pulse,

you would make a
coherent superposition of many eigenstates.

So many eigenstates,
well, they're so densely packed that this
would have quantum beats.

But the density of
states was so high that the quantum beats
would be at a long time,

compared to the
radiative lifetime. And so, you don't see
any quantum beats.

So what ends up
happening is you create this coherent superposition
of many zero order states.

And it dephases, and
that dephasing time

means that the brightness has--
you started out phasing up. You have a bright state.

The brightness goes away. It doesn't go away,
it just dephases

so that, instead of having
all of your brightness working for you, you've
got-- you've divided up

into many little pieces. And so, each of these
states decays slowly.

But that's going in
the wrong direction,

because we want the
lifetime to be short. But the brightness

And we forget the fact

up happening is

that the Fourier
transform of what you see

are closely spaced,

there's a little bit of
oscillation at long time. But mostly, the
fluorescence is--

the bright character is
dephased before you get any kind of partial recurrence.

And this explains--
so we have the quantum

yield is going to
be the radiative

In the strong

different system that you're unexpected-- that is

where you don't

the relative energies

of the broad state

the sharp state can tune

And this is
completely unexpected. And it leads to
a profound change in the dynamics, which
is actually true,

soluble problem. And you get insights. And it turns out, the
algebra for solving

It is trivial in the
